executive_summary: The Convenience Stores industry in the US has withstood fierce competition by continuing to offer convenience and value and expanding the variety of fresh and healthy products available. Businesses have increasingly shifted product mixes to include food service products to counteract declining cigarette use and have focused more on satisfying demand for quick and easy meal options.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Convenience Stores Scramble to Keep Up With Health Consciousness
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Convenience stores have noted the trend in consumer preferences for healthier options and have responded by expanding their fresh food offerings like fresh fruit, vegetables, salads, protein packages and other healthier grab-and-go food options. However, expanding fresh food offerings is challenging due to shorter shelf life and spoilage issues.

The industry is moderately concentrated, with the top 4 players accounting for 34.3% and top 8 players accounting for 46.6% of revenue in 2024. The largest player is 7-Eleven with 15.5% market share, focused on expanding fresh food program and delivery services.

Industry revenue is expected to have grown at a CAGR of 2.8% over the last few years to $45.5 billion in 2024, aided by high employment levels pre-pandemic. However, the pandemic negatively impacted revenue due to reduced foot traffic. Going forward, revenue is projected to grow at 2.2% annually to $50.7 billion by 2029 driven by focus on convenience and fresh food.

Work-from-home policies during the pandemic disrupted commuting schedules and reduced foot traffic for convenience stores. However, foot traffic has rebounded with employees returning to work and seeking cheaper food options from convenience stores. The pandemic also accelerated adoption of contactless payment options.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The Rise of High-End Convenience Stores
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Major companies have launched high-end convenience store concepts offering premium food/beverage options and digital innovations. These appeal to higher-income customers and have contributed to increasing industry revenue through higher-priced products.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: A Strong Economy Will Fuel Competition From Other Markets
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As domestic US travel increases, gas station convenience stores will compete for customers on the move, potentially diverting traffic from standalone stores. Rising disposable income will also shift consumer behavior towards bulk purchasing from supermarkets and e-commerce.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Embracing Digital Innovation Enables Companies to Remain Competitive
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Implementing digital innovations like contactless ordering/payment and online ordering/delivery will be critical for convenience stores to stay competitive against larger retailers and digital substitutes by enhancing convenience.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Rising Excise Taxes on Tobacco Products Will Pressure the Industry
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As tobacco excise taxes increase, higher prices will discourage tobacco purchases, hurting revenue for stores reliant on these sales. Convenience stores must diversify offerings and emphasize alternatives like nicotine pouches.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Convenience Store Giants Will Continue to Absorb Smaller Companies
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Consolidation will rise due to price competition, as larger stores leverage economies of scale for lower prices. Smaller companies unable to compete on price will struggle and be acquired.

industry_definition: Operators in the Convenience Stores industry primarily sell basic food, beverage and tobacco merchandise in convenient locations that are generally open during extended hours. This report also includes e-commerce sales from these establishments.
key_trends: Convenience stores in the US compete with each other in various ways. Price, product selection and establishment location are all vital competitive factors within the industry.

Other retailers that offer similar products are a source of competition for convenience stores. Primary competitors include traditional supermarkets, grocery stores and gas stations with convenience stores.

The COVID-19 pandemic hurt the industry in 2020. Because convenience stores rely heavily on foot traffic, temporary lockdowns, social distancing guidelines, and work-from-home arrangements decreased demand for industry services.

Increased competition and changing consumer preferences have caused businesses to adjust their operating strategies. This includes stores expanding their product offerings with healthier options and adopting digital innovations, like contactless payments, to increase customer satisfaction.

7-Eleven is the largest company in the US convenience store industry. It has gained market share by expanding its physical footprint, implementing innovative strategies and focusing on strengthening brand reputation and customer loyalty.

Successful companies in the industry provide an extensive array of price-competitive products. Low levels of product differentiation in the industry make it crucial for companies to have highly demanded products in stock at competitive prices.
Convenience Stores in the US must adhere to all common labor and safety regulations. Also, since convenience stores sell food, they are subject to rules set by the US Food and Drug Administration.

Companies in the Convenience Stores industry don't receive significant public industry assistance. However, businesses benefit from some trade associations, including the Association for Convenience and Fuel Retailing.

Purchases are the most significant cost for Convenience Stores in the US. This is typical of most retail industries since they must purchase inventory from upstream suppliers and keep products in stock to attract and satisfy customers.
Increased competition in the industry has put pressure on profit. Despite revenue expansion, profit has shrunk as price-based competition has risen.

Most establishments in this industry are located in densely populated areas of the US. Because this industry does not include convenience stores with gas stations, companies rely heavily on foot traffic, making it strategic to locate in a highly populated area.

An overall dip in the number of smokers in the US has shifted demand for products in the Convenience Stores industry. A drop in demand for cigarettes has given way to an increase in demand for alternative products like nicotine pouches and e-cigarettes.
Increased regulations have impacted tobacco sales. The legal age to purchase tobacco products in the US increased, causing revenue from the sales of tobacco products to consumers under 21 to drop.

market_segmentation.segment_description: This market includes all consumers under the age of 25. As of December 2019, the legal age for purchasing tobacco products in the US is 21. Convenience stores are prohibited from selling cigarettes and tobacco products to consumers under 21; the previous age was 18, affecting revenue from this segment in the current period. Younger adults typically have less disposable income than their older counterparts, limiting their purchase power. Still, convenience store products are relatively low-cost, which sustains some level of demand from younger consumers.

This market segment includes adults between the ages of 25 and 44. Adults in this age group are busy growing families or careers and are inclined to purchase convenience store food due to ease, availability and efficiency. Many convenience stores have increased their offerings to include healthier and fresher food options, which has particularly appealed to consumers in this age demographic.

This segment includes consumers aged between 45 and 64. Demand from consumers in this demographic can vary since the younger end is primarily in the middle of their careers while the older end has reached or is approaching retirement. This range can show differences in consumer behavior; however, members in this segment are similar because they tend to have stable incomes. With higher levels of disposable income and fewer social stigmas surrounding tobacco use for this age range, this group purchases more tobacco products than any other. Convenience stores are known to be a logical option for quickly purchasing these products.

This segment includes adults over the age of 65. Consumers in this age demographic purchase slightly more tobacco products than consumers under age 25 but less than the other two age groups. As consumers reach retirement age, they are less likely to walk long distances or commute on foot. Older adults prefer gas stations with convenience stores not included in this industry or more extensive markets they can drive.

products_and_services.product_description: The visual appears to be a pie chart showing the product and service categories for convenience stores. The largest category is Products & Services at 38.7%, followed by Tobacco Products at 18.8%, and Food Service at 8%.

Tobacco products include cigarettes, cigars, smokeless tobacco products, electronic smoking devices and smoking accessories. Electronic smoking devices and some smokeless tobacco products contain nicotine derived from tobacco even if they don't contain tobacco itself; therefore, they are considered tobacco products, according to the US Surgeon General.

Food items include hot and cold food prepared on-site; packaged meals and hot, cold and frozen beverages. Freshly brewed coffee is famous among commuters, for example, who grab their morning cup on the way to work.
Packaged beverages include bottled beverages like water, soft drinks, energy drinks and alternative beverages.
This segment accounts for all other products sold by convenience stores, including cleaning products, magazines, stationery, fresh flowers, personal care items and lottery tickets.

This segment includes prepackaged candy and snacks, both salty and sweet. Snacking has become more popular as Americans have become more time-constrained. For example, commuters who don't have time for a complete meal may stop by a convenience store for snacks.
Convenience stores in eligible states sell beer. According to 2020 data from the Beer Institute, convenience stores account for nearly one-third of all beer purchased in the United States.

tier_1_suppliers: Frozen Food Wholesaling in the US
Soft Drink, Baked Goods & Other Grocery Wholesaling in the US
Cigarette & Tobacco Products Wholesaling in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Snack Food Production in the US
Frozen Food Production in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Convenience stores, known for their strategic locations and extended hours, often charge higher prices for nonessential goods. This premium is essentially for the speed and expanded accessibility they provide. As disposable income levels rise, consumers can increasingly frequent these stores and willingly spend more on each visit for convenience.
Although sales of sugary snacks like chocolate bars and ice cream have continued to grow in the past few years, demand has increased at a lesser rate than the rise in demand for healthier options.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast region has the highest percentage of both establishments (27%) and population (28%), indicating a correlation between population density and number of business establishments in an area.

regulations_points.regulation_title: FAMILY SMOKING PREVENTION AND TOBACCO CONTROL ACT (TOBACCO CONTROL ACT)
regulations_points.regulation_description: The Tobacco Control Act grants the Food and Drug Administration control over the sale and marketing of tobacco products. The Act prohibits the distribution of free samples and the sale of flavored cigarette products and requires health warnings on all tobacco product packaging. An amendment to the Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act in December 2019 also raised the legal age for buying tobacco products in the US to 21.

regulations_points.regulation_title: DODD-FRANK WALL STREET REFORM AND CONSUMER PROTECTION ACT
regulations_points.regulation_description: The 2010 Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act limited the interchange fees that convenience store retailers previously shouldered for debit cards. Credit cards are excluded from this regulation. The Act also enabled convenience stores to offer a discount to customers using a certain kind of payment and permitted retailers to set a minimum purchase amount (up to $10.00) for credit cards.

Convenience stores must abide by all pertinent OSHA rules and regulations, maintaining a clean and healthy environment for workers. Requirements include marked exit routes and emergency planning, safety precautions regarding equipment, providing personal protective equipment when necessary and safeguarding against workplace violence. The agency imposes fines for violations of its standards.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The mature life cycle stage of the industry is a factor for increased barriers to entry.

basis_points.basis_title: Price, product selection and establishment location are vital competitive factors
basis_points.basis_description: Convenience stores in the US compete with each other in various ways. Price, product selection and establishment location are all vital competitive factors within the industry.

basis_points.basis_title: Competition from other retailers selling similar products
basis_points.basis_description: Other retailers that offer similar products are a source of competition for convenience stores. Primary competitors include traditional supermarkets, grocery stores and gas stations with convenience stores.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Saturated markets encourage big convenience stores to absorb smaller ones
concentration_points.concentration_description: Convenience stores have trouble differentiating since product lines are nearly identical from one store to another. Geographic expansion is an alternative way to overcome competition. Large convenience stores with sufficient means acquire smaller stores to broaden their geographic footprint. Accessing new geographic markets is crucial to growing a convenience store brand.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Fresh Food Keeps Purchase Costs High
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Fresh food continues to be a significant expense for convenience stores looking to appeal to the expanding pool of health-conscious shoppers. It also risks expiring before it is purchased, requiring businesses to replace it and driving up purchase costs.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Credit Card Fees and Declining Smoking Rates Squeeze Convenience Stores' Profit
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Industry profit has been pressured. A surge in credit card usage has accelerated convenience store transaction fees, squeezing profit. Also, a shrinking number of smokers has reduced sales of high-profit items like cigarettes.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Convenience stores need a handful of workers to stock and sell items and manage store operations, but the average wage is low. Stores that are located near populated areas can easily find labor.

volatility_points.volatility_title: HIGHER DISPOSABLE INCOMES LEND GREATER VALUE TO CONVENIENCE STORES
volatility_points.volatility_description: Broader socioeconomic conditions determine the level of foot traffic to convenience stores. When disposable income levels rise and unemployment falls, as is the case now that the post-pandemic recovery is well underway, more people are employed and on the go with money to spend. Commuters, for example, often use convenience stores as a pit stop.

volatility_points.volatility_title: UPSTREAM COMMODITY PRICES TRICKLE DOWN TO CONSUMERS
volatility_points.volatility_description: Many common convenience store goods are subject to price volatility for raw ingredients, including tobacco and sugar. Commodity prices of several agricultural products have risen in recent years, spurring convenience stores to mark up prices. Specifically, cocoa and sugar prices have surged over the past few years because of increased demand and a lack of supply due to weather events in producing countries.

Smoking rates for traditional cigarettes have consistently declined because of increasingly stringent federal regulations that have raised prices and raised the purchase age for tobacco products to 21. To lessen the loss in revenue from tobacco products, convenience stores have stocked up on e-cigarettes, nicotine pouches and vape pens because their popularity has overshadowed that of traditional tobacco.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Embracing contactless payment to increase convenience
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Convenience stores in the US have steadily been incorporating contactless payment methods such as Apple Pay and various mobile wallets, which expand consumers' payment options and enhance the ease of transactions. Key businesses have also launched mobile applications that facilitate digital payments and offer incentives to build brand loyalty, further enhancing the benefits of payment alternatives.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Health consciousness drives healthier food options
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Rising health consciousness among the US population has led convenience stores to expand their product offerings to include healthier options. Historically, convenience stores have focused on offering affordable packaged and processed foods. Companies have now expanded to provide more nutritious options like prepackaged salads, fruit, kombucha and other similar items.

FAQs.question: Are your customers heavily price-conscious?
FAQs.answer: Consumers looking for a quick beverage or bite to eat are not likely to be very price-conscious. Also, many high-income consumers have pushed operators to provide more premium and organic products.

FAQs.question: What are the key requirements from the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) for convenience stores?
FAQs.answer: Convenience stores must abide by all pertinent OSHA rules and regulations, maintaining a clean and healthy environment for workers. Requirements include marked exit routes and emergency planning, safety precautions regarding equipment, providing personal protective equipment when necessary and safeguarding against workplace violence. The agency imposes fines for violations of its standards.

FAQs.question: What assistance is available for the convenience store industry?
FAQs.answer: The Association for Convenience and Fuel Retailing (NACS) provides research and analysis on industry trends and issues. It also provides networking opportunities to convenience stores around the globe. The NACS show, occurring annually, is one of the largest trade shows in the United States. Convenience stores can benefit from this association by gaining information on key consumer trends that can help them stay competitive.

FAQs.question: Are your company's sales heavily dependent on the health of the US economy?
FAQs.answer: Consumers are less likely to spend on discretionary goods when the economy suffers.

FAQs.question: Has your company explored acquisition opportunities to expand reach and reduce overhead expenses?
FAQs.answer: Acquisition activity has increased as larger operators in the industry can attain more significant economies of scale. The largest player, 7-Eleven, is part of Japanese operator Seven & I Holdings Co. The second largest player Alimentation Couche Tard, has operations overseas as well and is looking to expand their global footprint.

FAQs.question: Do volatile input costs negatively influence your company's sales?
FAQs.answer: Volatile input costs can negatively impact convenience store sales. Fluctuating costs can lead to unpredictable pricing, dissuading customers and reducing sales.

FAQs.question: Does your company use point-of-sale (POS) systems to keep the most popular products in stock?
FAQs.answer: POS systems have become particularly important for chain convenience stores that rely on software to manage inventory, customer relations and financials. Stores that use POS systems benefit from having an optimal product mix and lower inventory levels.

FAQs.question: How does your company use new technology in its operations?
FAQs.answer: Stores that offer contactless payments benefit as the checkout process is much more efficient.

FAQs.question: Have any regulatory expenses significantly impacted profit?
FAQs.answer: Debit and credit swipe fees have drastically cut into industry profit as card providers generally charge merchandisers hefty fees to use their services.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure all health and safety requirements are met?
FAQs.answer: Similar to most retailers, operators must comply with regulations set by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration.

FAQs.question: How does your company's inventory turnover compare to major competitors'?
FAQs.answer: Keeping fresh stock is crucial to operators' success.

FAQs.question: How does your company's profit compare with your main competitors'?
FAQs.answer: Profit is typically low but may vary among operators. Larger companies in the space generally benefit from economies of scale. On the other hand, small operators can provide more tailored products for their respective areas, which can boost revenue and profitability.

FAQs.question: Is your company dominant in any particular regional markets? What range does your company have in terms of proximity to key markets?
FAQs.answer: Convenience stores should be located near residential areas to provide ease of access. Locations should also be remote from other food stores, including supermarkets and quick-service restaurants.

FAQs.question: How do you maintain a customer base? What service qualities are important?
FAQs.answer: Convenience store operators need to provide friendly and helpful service to ensure repeat purchases. In addition, establishing a reputation for quick service is essential.

FAQs.question: How do you maintain optimum stock levels? What factors affect demand and stock levels?
FAQs.answer: Operators must minimize unnecessary stock buildup while ensuring that popular products are always available.

FAQs.question: Do you have increased traffic at urban locations? Do you plan to extend operators into more urban areas?
FAQs.answer: Consumers living in urban populations tend to purchase items more frequently from industry operators instead of wholesale clubs and supercenters. Consequently, as more consumers live in urban areas, foot traffic to supermarkets and grocery stores increases, lifting industry revenue.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor the healthy eating index? When American diets are healthier, does your company benefit or struggle?
FAQs.answer: As consumers become more health-conscious, measured by the healthy eating index, they tend to purchase a greater variety of all-natural and organic products from convenience stores.
